headline: Malaria prophylaxis recommended for most safari destinations
summary: Most popular safari destinations in East and Southern Africa carry malaria risk year-round, though levels vary by season and location. Prophylaxis is strongly recommended for first-time visitors. Consult a travel medicine specialist 4-6 weeks before departure for current recommendations specific to your itinerary and health profile.

assumptions.text: Tanzania, Kenya, Botswana, and Zimbabwe have significant malaria transmission.
Modern prophylaxis (Malarone, doxycycline) is highly effective when taken correctly.
Risk tolerance, health conditions, and previous exposure affect the decision.

gains: Modern drugs have manageable side effects
Insurance and medical support often require prophylaxis
losses: Potential side effects vary by drug

change_conditions: If visiting malaria-free areas (Cape Town, some Namibia), prophylaxis may not be needed.
If you have contraindications to all prophylaxis options, discuss alternatives with your doctor.
If visiting during dry season in low-risk areas, risk is reduced but not eliminated.
If pregnant or with young children, consult specialist for specific guidance.
